intro: Heteropolygonatum marmoratum, commonly known as the marbled clubmoss, is a rare and endangered species belonging to the family Lycopodiaceae. It is characterized by its distinctive marbled patterns on its leaves, which give it its common name. The plant typically grows in moist, shaded environments such as forests and rocky crevices. Its sporophyte structure consists of a short stem with spirally arranged leaves, and it produces spores in specialized structures called strobila. Due to habitat loss and environmental changes, this plant is highly sensitive to ecological disturbances.
